newsitem.title: USA: Tosco to buy 76 Products for about $2 billion.
newsitem.headline: Tosco to buy 76 Products for about $2 billion.

text.p: Tosco Corp. said Monday it agreed to buy 76 Products Co., the refining and marketing unit of Unocal Corp., in a deal worth about $2 billion that will create a powerhouse gasoline retailer on the West Coast.

The price includes $1.4 billion for 76 Products' fixed assets, about $400 million for inventories and up to $250 million in future profits if gasoline profit margins rise in the next seven years, the companies said.
El Segundo, Calif.-based Unocal said it expects to record a $375 million after-tax loss from the sale.
"This acquisition makes Tosco the largest independent refiner and marketer in the United States," said Thomas O'Malley, Tosco's chairman and chief executive officer.
"On the retail side, the 76 retail system, added to Tosco's existing California properties, makes Tosco the third-largest retailer in the state of California."

The 76 system includes about 1,350 gasoline stations and three refineries in California with capacity of 250,000 barrels a day. As part of the deal, Tosco will acquire the 76 brand name in refining and marketing worldwide.

The deal also includes a distribution system including 13 oil storage terminals, three modern tankers and 1,500 miles of crude oil and product pipeline, as well as Unocal's extensive lubricants manufacturing, distribution and marketing business.
Tosco will assume limited environmental liabilities.

With the ability to process about 1 million barrels of crude oil a day, Tosco will rival the nation's largest refiners, Amoco Corp., Exxon Corp. and Mobil Corp., Salomon Brothers analyst Paul Ting said.
Costa Mesa, Calif.-based 76 Products also has retail outlets and terminals in Hawaii, which will provide a new market for Tosco, which operates Circle K convenience stores.
Wall Street applauded the deal, and Tosco stock jumped $11.625 to $71.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. Unocal added $1.125 to $40.625, also on the NYSE.
The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 1997, subject to approval by both companies' boards, Tosco shareholders and regulators.
The companies and analysts said they do not expect regulators to hold up the deal on antitrust grounds.
Stamford, Conn.-based Tosco said the merger will generate substantial selling, general and administrative cost savings.
Tosco will fund the acquisition with a combination of debt and equity.
Unocal said the sale is part of the company's long-term strategy to grow by pursuing large projects in Asia.

"With this sale, we can focus on expanding our role as a major international energy producer and project developer and on strengthening our domestic U.S. oil and gas operations in the Louisiana/Gulf of Mexico region," Unocal Chairman Roger Beach said in a statement.

"They got a good value out of this," said Anit Sen at Wall Street brokerage Oppenheimer & Co., noting that the sale will reduce Unocal's debt and save $200 million to $250 million in capital expenditures.

Tosco, with more than $11 billion in annual revenues, is one of the nation's largest independent refiners and marketers of petroleum products, and is the nation's largest operator of company-owned convenience stores.
